cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior.
Security System Extension records events related to extension code being loaded by the security subsystem.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000327-GPOS-00127, SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000463-GPOS-00207, SRG-OS-000468-GPOS-00212

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Audit Security System Extension

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Advanced Audit Policy Configuration >> System Audit Policies >> System >> "Audit Security System Extension"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Server 2016 must be configured to audit System - System Integrity successes.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224912
RULE ID:SV-224912r958732

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Generate audit records for the event types defined in AU-2 c that include the audit record content defined in AU-3.
Log the execution of privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior.
System Integrity records events related to violations of integrity to the security subsystem.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000327-GPOS-00127, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00216, SRG-OS-000477-GPOS-00222

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Advanced Audit Policy Configuration >> System Audit Policies >> System >> "Audit System Integrity"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Server 2016 must be configured to audit System - System Integrity failures.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224913
RULE ID:SV-224913r958732

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Generate audit records for the event types defined in AU-2 c that include the audit record content defined in AU-3.
Log the execution of privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior.
System Integrity records events related to violations of integrity to the security subsystem.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000327-GPOS-00127, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00216, SRG-OS-000477-GPOS-00222

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Advanced Audit Policy Configuration >> System Audit Policies >> System >> "Audit System Integrity"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000010

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The display of slide shows on the lock screen must be disabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224914
RULE ID:SV-224914r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Slide shows that are displayed on the lock screen could display sensitive information to unauthorized personnel. Turning off this feature will limit access to the information to a logged-on user.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Prevent enabling lock screen slide show

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Control Panel >> Personalization >> "Prevent enabling lock screen slide show"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: WDigest Authentication must be disabled on Windows Server 2016.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224915
RULE ID:SV-224915r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: When the WDigest Authentication protocol is enabled, plain-text passwords are stored in the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS), exposing them to theft. WDigest is disabled by default in Windows Server 2016. This setting ensures this is enforced.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> MS Security Guide >> "WDigest Authentication (disabling may require KB2871997)"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: This policy setting requires the installation of the SecGuide custom templates included with the STIG package. "SecGuide.admx" and " SecGuide.adml" must be copied to the \Windows\PolicyDefinitions and \Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-US directories respectively.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000040

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) source routing must be configured to the highest protection level to prevent IP source routing.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224916
RULE ID:SV-224916r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Configuring the system to disable IPv6 source routing protects against spoofing.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: MSS: (DisableIPSourceRouting IPv6) IP source routing protection level

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> MSS (Legacy) >> "MSS: (DisableIPSourceRouting IPv6) IP source routing protection level (protects against packet spoofing)"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with "Highest protection, source routing is completely disabled" selected.

This policy setting requires the installation of the MSS-Legacy custom templates included with the STIG package. "MSS-Legacy.admx" and "MSS-Legacy.adml" must be copied to the \Windows\PolicyDefinitions and \Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-US directories respectively.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000050

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Source routing must be configured to the highest protection level to prevent Internet Protocol (IP) source routing.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224917
RULE ID:SV-224917r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Configuring the system to disable IP source routing protects against spoofing.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: MSS: (DisableIPSourceRouting) IP source routing protection level

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> MSS (Legacy) >> "MSS: (DisableIPSourceRouting) IP source routing protection level (protects against packet spoofing)"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with "Highest protection, source routing is completely disabled" selected.

This policy setting requires the installation of the MSS-Legacy custom templates included with the STIG package. "MSS-Legacy.admx" and "MSS-Legacy.adml" must be copied to the \Windows\PolicyDefinitions and \Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-US directories respectively.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000060

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Server 2016 must be configured to prevent Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects from overriding Open Shortest Path First (OSPF)-generated routes.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224918
RULE ID:SV-224918r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing ICMP redirect of routes can lead to traffic not being routed properly. When disabled, this forces ICMP to be routed via the shortest path first.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: MSS: (EnableICMPRedirect) Allow ICMP redirects to override OSPF generated routes

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> MSS (Legacy) >> "MSS: (EnableICMPRedirect) Allow ICMP redirects to override OSPF generated routes"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: This policy setting requires the installation of the MSS-Legacy custom templates included with the STIG package. "MSS-Legacy.admx" and "MSS-Legacy.adml" must be copied to the \Windows\PolicyDefinitions and \Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-US directories respectively.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000070

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Server 2016 must be configured to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224919
RULE ID:SV-224919r958902

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Protect against or limit the effects of organization-defined types of denial of service events.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Configuring the system to ignore name release requests, except from WINS servers, prevents a denial of service (DoS) attack. The DoS consists of sending a NetBIOS name release request to the server for each entry in the server's cache, causing a response delay in the normal operation of the server's WINS resolution capability.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: MSS: (NoNameReleaseOnDemand) Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> MSS (Legacy) >> "MSS: (NoNameReleaseOnDemand) Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: This policy setting requires the installation of the MSS-Legacy custom templates included with the STIG package. "MSS-Legacy.admx" and "MSS-Legacy.adml" must be copied to the \Windows\PolicyDefinitions and \Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-US directories respectively.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000080

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Insecure logons to an SMB server must be disabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224920
RULE ID:SV-224920r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Insecure guest logons allow unauthenticated access to shared folders. Shared resources on a system must require authentication to establish proper access.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Enable insecure guest logons

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Network >> Lanman Workstation >> "Enable insecure guest logons"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Hardened UNC paths must be defined to require mutual authentication and integrity for at least the \ \SYSVOL and \ \NETLOGON shares.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224921
RULE ID:SV-224921r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Additional security requirements are applied to Universal Naming Convention (UNC) paths specified in hardened UNC paths before allowing access to them. This aids in preventing tampering with or spoofing of connections to these paths.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Network >> Network Provider >> "Hardened UNC Paths" to "Enabled"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: with at least the following configured in "Hardened UNC Paths": (click the "Show" button to display)
xhtml:p.xhtml:code:
Value Name: \\*\SYSVOL
Value: RequireMutualAuthentication=1, RequireIntegrity=1

Value Name: \\*\NETLOGON
Value: RequireMutualAuthentication=1, RequireIntegrity=1

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000100

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Command line data must be included in process creation events.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224922
RULE ID:SV-224922r958422

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Generate audit records containing the organization-defined additional information that is to be included in the audit records.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior.

Enabling "Include command line data for process creation events" will record the command line information with the process creation events in the log. This can provide additional detail when malware has run on a system.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Include command line in process creation events

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Audit Process Creation >> "Include command line in process creation events"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000110

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Server 2016 virtualization-based security must be enabled with the platform security level configured to Secure Boot or Secure Boot with DMA Protection.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224923
RULE ID:SV-224923r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Virtualization-based security (VBS) provides the platform for the additional security features Credential Guard and virtualization-based protection of code integrity. Secure Boot is the minimum security level, with DMA protection providing additional memory protection. DMA Protection requires a CPU that supports input/output memory management unit (IOMMU).

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn On Virtualization Based Security
Turn On Virtualization Based Security: Select Platform Security Level

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Device Guard >> "Turn On Virtualization Based Security"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with "Secure Boot" or "Secure Boot and DMA Protection" selected.
A Microsoft TechNet article on Credential Guard, including system requirement details, can be found at the following link:

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000140

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Early Launch Antimalware, Boot-Start Driver Initialization Policy must prevent boot drivers identified as bad.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224924
RULE ID:SV-224924r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Compromised boot drivers can introduce malware prior to protection mechanisms that load after initialization. The Early Launch Antimalware driver can limit allowed drivers based on classifications determined by the malware protection application. At a minimum, drivers determined to be bad must not be allowed.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Boot-Start Driver Initialization Policy

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: The default behavior is for Early Launch Antimalware - Boot-Start Driver Initialization policy to enforce "Good, unknown and bad but critical" (preventing "bad").
If this needs to be corrected or a more secure setting is desired, configure the policy value for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Early Launch Antimalware >> "Boot-Start Driver Initialization Policy"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Not Configured" or "Enabled" with any option other than "All" selected.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000150

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Group Policy objects must be reprocessed even if they have not changed.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224925
RULE ID:SV-224925r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Registry entries for group policy settings can potentially be changed from the required configuration. This could occur as part of troubleshooting or by a malicious process on a compromised system. Enabling this setting and then selecting the "Process even if the Group Policy objects have not changed" option ensures the policies will be reprocessed even if none have been changed. This way, any unauthorized changes are forced to match the domain-based group policy settings again.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Configure registry policy processing: Process even if the Group Policy objects have not changed

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Group Policy >> "Configure registry policy processing"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with the option "Process even if the Group Policy objects have not changed" selected.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000160

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Downloading print driver packages over HTTP must be prevented.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224926
RULE ID:SV-224926r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Some features may communicate with the vendor, sending system information or downloading data or components for the feature. Turning off this capability will prevent potentially sensitive information from being sent outside the enterprise and will prevent uncontrolled updates to the system.
This setting prevents the computer from downloading print driver packages over HTTP.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn off downloading of print drivers over HTTP

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Internet Communication Management >> Internet Communication settings >> "Turn off downloading of print drivers over HTTP"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000170

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Printing over HTTP must be prevented.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224927
RULE ID:SV-224927r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Some features may communicate with the vendor, sending system information or downloading data or components for the feature. Turning off this capability will prevent potentially sensitive information from being sent outside the enterprise and will prevent uncontrolled updates to the system.
This setting prevents the client computer from printing over HTTP, which allows the computer to print to printers on the intranet as well as the Internet.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn off printing over HTTP

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Internet Communication Management >> Internet Communication settings >> "Turn off printing over HTTP"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000180

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The network selection user interface (UI) must not be displayed on the logon screen.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224928
RULE ID:SV-224928r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling interaction with the network selection UI allows users to change connections to available networks without signing in to Windows.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Do not display network selection UI

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Logon >> "Do not display network selection UI"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000210

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Users must be prompted to authenticate when the system wakes from sleep (on battery).
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224929
RULE ID:SV-224929r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: A system that does not require authentication when resuming from sleep may provide access to unauthorized users. Authentication must always be required when accessing a system. This setting ensures users are prompted for a password when the system wakes from sleep (on battery).

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Require a password when a computer wakes (on battery)

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Power Management >> Sleep Settings >> "Require a password when a computer wakes (on battery)"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000220

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Users must be prompted to authenticate when the system wakes from sleep (plugged in).
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID:V-224930
RULE ID:SV-224930r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: A system that does not require authentication when resuming from sleep may provide access to unauthorized users. Authentication must always be required when accessing a system. This setting ensures users are prompted for a password when the system wakes from sleep (plugged in).

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Require a password when a computer wakes (plugged in)

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> System >> Power Management >> Sleep Settings >> "Require a password when a computer wakes (plugged in)"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Application Compatibility Program Inventory must be prevented from collecting data and sending the information to Microsoft.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224931
RULE ID: SV-224931r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Some features may communicate with the vendor, sending system information or downloading data or components for the feature. Turning off this capability will prevent potentially sensitive information from being sent outside the enterprise and will prevent uncontrolled updates to the system.
This setting will prevent the Program Inventory from collecting data about a system and sending the information to Microsoft.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Application Compatibility >> "Turn off Inventory Collector"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000250

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: AutoPlay must be turned off for non-volume devices.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224932
RULE ID: SV-224932r958804

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent program execution in accordance with organization-defined policies, rules of behavior, and/or access agreements regarding software program usage and restrictions; rules authorizing the terms and conditions of software program usage.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing AutoPlay to execute may introduce malicious code to a system. AutoPlay begins reading from a drive as soon as media is inserted into the drive. As a result, the setup file of programs or music on audio media may start. This setting will disable AutoPlay for non-volume devices, such as Media Transfer Protocol (MTP) devices.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Disallow Autoplay for non-volume devices

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> AutoPlay Policies >> "Disallow Autoplay for non-volume devices"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000260

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The default AutoRun behavior must be configured to prevent AutoRun commands.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224933
RULE ID: SV-224933r958804

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent program execution in accordance with organization-defined policies, rules of behavior, and/or access agreements regarding software program usage and restrictions; rules authorizing the terms and conditions of software program usage.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing AutoRun commands to execute may introduce malicious code to a system. Configuring this setting prevents AutoRun commands from executing.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Set the default behavior for AutoRun

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> AutoPlay Policies >> "Set the default behavior for AutoRun"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with "Do not execute any autorun commands" selected.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: AutoPlay must be disabled for all drives.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224934
RULE ID: SV-224934r958804

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent program execution in accordance with organization-defined policies, rules of behavior, and/or access agreements regarding software program usage and restrictions; rules authorizing the terms and conditions of software program usage.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing AutoPlay to execute may introduce malicious code to a system. AutoPlay begins reading from a drive as soon media is inserted into the drive. As a result, the setup file of programs or music on audio media may start. By default, AutoPlay is disabled on removable drives, such as the floppy disk drive (but not the CD-ROM drive) and on network drives. Enabling this policy disables AutoPlay on all drives.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> AutoPlay Policies >> "Turn off AutoPlay"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000280

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Administrator accounts must not be enumerated during elevation.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224935
RULE ID: SV-224935r958518

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Enumeration of administrator accounts when elevating can provide part of the logon information to an unauthorized user. This setting configures the system to always require users to type in a username and password to elevate a running application.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Enumerate administrator accounts on elevation

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Credential User Interface >> "Enumerate administrator accounts on elevation"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Telemetry must be configured to Security or Basic.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224936
RULE ID: SV-224936r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Some features may communicate with the vendor, sending system information or downloading data or components for the feature. Limiting this capability will prevent potentially sensitive information from being sent outside the enterprise. The "Security" option for Telemetry configures the lowest amount of data, effectively none outside of the Malicious Software Removal Tool (MSRT), Defender, and telemetry client settings. "Basic" sends basic diagnostic and usage data and may be required to support some Microsoft services.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Data Collection and Preview Builds>> "Allow Telemetry"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with "0 - Security [Enterprise Only]" or "1 - Basic" selected in "Options".

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000300

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Application event log size must be configured to 32768 KB or greater.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224937
RULE ID: SV-224937r958752

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Allocate audit log storage capacity to accommodate organization-defined audit log retention requirements.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Inadequate log size will cause the log to fill up quickly. This may prevent audit events from being recorded properly and require frequent attention by administrative personnel.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Application: Specify the maximum log file size (KB)

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Event Log Service >> Application >> "Specify the maximum log file size (KB)"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with a "Maximum Log Size (KB)" of "32768" or greater.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000310

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Security event log size must be configured to 196608 KB or greater.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224938
RULE ID: SV-224938r958752

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Allocate audit log storage capacity to accommodate organization-defined audit log retention requirements.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Inadequate log size will cause the log to fill up quickly. This may prevent audit events from being recorded properly and require frequent attention by administrative personnel.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Security: Specify the maximum log file size (KB)

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Event Log Service >> Security >> "Specify the maximum log file size (KB)"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" with a "Maximum Log Size (KB)" of "196608" or greater.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000320

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The System event log size must be configured to 32768 KB or greater.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224939
RULE ID: SV-224939r958752

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Allocate audit log storage capacity to accommodate organization-defined audit log retention requirements.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Inadequate log size will cause the log to fill up quickly. This may prevent audit events from being recorded properly and require frequent attention by administrative personnel.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: System: Specify the maximum log file size (KB)

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Event Log Service >> System >> "Specify the maximum log file size (KB)" to "Enabled" with a "Maximum Log Size (KB)" of "32768" or greater

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000330

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Server 2016 Windows SmartScreen must be enabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224940
RULE ID: SV-224940r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Windows SmartScreen helps protect systems from programs downloaded from the internet that may be malicious. Enabling SmartScreen will warn users of potentially malicious programs.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Configure Windows Defender SmartScreen

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> File Explorer >> "Configure Windows SmartScreen" to "Enabled"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Explorer Data Execution Prevention must be enabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224941
RULE ID: SV-224941r958928

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement organization-defined controls to protect the system memory from unauthorized code execution.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Data Execution Prevention provides additional protection by performing checks on memory to help prevent malicious code from running. This setting will prevent Data Execution Prevention from being turned off for File Explorer.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: The default behavior is for data execution prevention to be turned on for File Explorer.
If this needs to be corrected, configure the policy value for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> File Explorer >> "Turn off Data Execution Prevention for Explorer" to "Not Configured" or "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000350

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Turning off File Explorer heap termination on corruption must be disabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224942
RULE ID: SV-224942r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Legacy plug-in applications may continue to function when a File Explorer session has become corrupt. Disabling this feature will prevent this.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn off heap termination on corruption

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: The default behavior is for File Explorer heap termination on corruption to be disabled.
If this needs to be corrected, configure the policy value for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> File Explorer >> "Turn off heap termination on corruption" to "Not Configured" or "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000360

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: File Explorer shell protocol must run in protected mode.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224943
RULE ID: SV-224943r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: The shell protocol will limit the set of folders that applications can open when run in protected mode. Restricting files an application can open to a limited set of folders increases the security of Windows.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn off shell protocol protected mode

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: The default behavior is for shell protected mode to be turned on for File Explorer.
If this needs to be corrected, configure the policy value for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> File Explorer >> "Turn off shell protocol protected mode" to "Not Configured" or "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000370

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Passwords must not be saved in the Remote Desktop Client.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224944
RULE ID: SV-224944r1050790

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The organization requires users to reauthenticate upon organization-defined circumstances or situations requiring reauthentication.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Saving passwords in the Remote Desktop Client could allow an unauthorized user to establish a remote desktop session to another system. The system must be configured to prevent users from saving passwords in the Remote Desktop Client.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00157, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Do not allow passwords to be saved

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Remote Desktop Services >> Remote Desktop Connection Client >> "Do not allow passwords to be saved" to "Enabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000380

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Local drives must be prevented from sharing with Remote Desktop Session Hosts.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224945
RULE ID: SV-224945r958524

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing users from sharing the local drives on their client computers with Remote Session Hosts that they access helps reduce possible exposure of sensitive data.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Do not allow drive redirection

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Remote Desktop Services >> Remote Desktop Session Host >> Device and Resource Redirection >> "Do not allow drive redirection" to "Enabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000390

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Remote Desktop Services must always prompt a client for passwords upon connection.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224946
RULE ID: SV-224946r1050790

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The organization requires users to reauthenticate upon organization-defined circumstances or situations requiring reauthentication.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability of users to supply passwords automatically as part of their remote desktop connection. Disabling this setting would allow anyone to use the stored credentials in a connection item to connect to the terminal server.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00157, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Always prompt for password upon connection

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Remote Desktop Services >> Remote Desktop Session Host >> Security >> "Always prompt for password upon connection" to "Enabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000400

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Remote Desktop Session Host must require secure Remote Procedure Call (RPC) communications.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224947
RULE ID: SV-224947r991554

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of remote access sessions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing unsecure RPC communication exposes the system to man-in-the-middle attacks and data disclosure attacks. A man-in-the-middle attack occurs when an intruder captures packets between a client and server and modifies them before allowing the packets to be exchanged. Usually the attacker will modify the information in the packets in an attempt to cause either the client or server to reveal sensitive information.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Require secure RPC communication

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Remote Desktop Services >> Remote Desktop Session Host >> Security >> "Require secure RPC communication" to "Enabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000410

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Remote Desktop Services must be configured with the client connection encryption set to High Level.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224948
RULE ID: SV-224948r991554

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of remote access sessions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote connections must be encrypted to prevent interception of data or sensitive information. Selecting "High Level" will ensure encryption of Remote Desktop Services sessions in both directions.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Set client connection encryption level

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Remote Desktop Services >> Remote Desktop Session Host >> Security >> "Set client connection encryption level" to "Enabled" with "High Level" selected

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000420

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Attachments must be prevented from being downloaded from RSS feeds.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224949
RULE ID: SV-224949r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Attachments from RSS feeds may not be secure. This setting will prevent attachments from being downloaded from RSS feeds.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Prevent downloading of enclosures

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> RSS Feeds >> "Prevent downloading of enclosures" to "Enabled"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Explorer Preview pane must be disabled for Windows Server 2016.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-236000
RULE ID: SV-236000r958478

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: A known vulnerability in Windows could allow the execution of malicious code by either opening a compromised document or viewing it in the Windows Preview pane.
Organizations must disable the Windows Preview pane and Windows Detail pane.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Ensure the following settings are configured for Windows Server 2016 locally or applied through group policy.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: User Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> File Explorer >> Explorer Frame Pane "Turn off Preview Pane
User Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> File Explorer >> Explorer Frame Pane "Turn on or off details pane"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to "Enabled" and "Configure details pane" to "Always hide".

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000430

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Basic authentication for RSS feeds over HTTP must not be used.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224951
RULE ID: SV-224951r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Basic authentication uses plain-text passwords that could be used to compromise a system. Disabling Basic authentication will reduce this potential.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn on Basic feed authentication over HTTP

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: The default behavior is for the Windows RSS platform to not use Basic authentication over HTTP connections.
If this needs to be corrected, configure the policy value for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> RSS Feeds >> "Turn on Basic feed authentication over HTTP" to "Not Configured" or "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000440

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Indexing of encrypted files must be turned off.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224952
RULE ID: SV-224952r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Indexing of encrypted files may expose sensitive data. This setting prevents encrypted files from being indexed.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Allow indexing of encrypted files

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Search >> "Allow indexing of encrypted files" to "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000450

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Users must be prevented from changing installation options.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224953
RULE ID: SV-224953r982210

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The information system prohibits user installation of software without explicit privileged status.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Installation options for applications are typically controlled by administrators. This setting prevents users from changing installation options that may bypass security features.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Allow user control over installs

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Installer >> "Allow user control over installs" to "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000460

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Installer Always install with elevated privileges option must be disabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224954
RULE ID: SV-224954r982210

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The information system prohibits user installation of software without explicit privileged status.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Standard user accounts must not be granted elevated privileges. Enabling Windows Installer to elevate privileges when installing applications can allow malicious persons and applications to gain full control of a system.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Always install with elevated privileges

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Installer >> "Always install with elevated privileges" to "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000470

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Users must be notified if a web-based program attempts to install software.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224955
RULE ID: SV-224955r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Web-based programs may attempt to install malicious software on a system. Ensuring users are notified if a web-based program attempts to install software allows them to refuse the installation.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Prevent Internet Explorer security prompt for Windows Installer scripts

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: The default behavior is for Internet Explorer to warn users and select whether to allow or refuse installation when a web-based program attempts to install software on the system.
If this needs to be corrected, configure the policy value for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Installer >> "Prevent Internet Explorer security prompt for Windows Installer scripts" to "Not Configured" or "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000480

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Automatically signing in the last interactive user after a system-initiated restart must be disabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224956
RULE ID: SV-224956r991591

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Windows can be configured to automatically sign the user back in after a Windows Update restart. Some protections are in place to help ensure this is done in a secure fashion; however, disabling this will prevent the caching of credentials for this purpose and also ensure the user is aware of the restart.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Sign-in last interactive user automatically after a system-initiated restart

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Logon Options >> "Sign-in last interactive user automatically after a system-initiated restart" to "Disabled"

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000490

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: PowerShell script block logging must be enabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224957
RULE ID: SV-224957r958422

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Generate audit records containing the organization-defined additional information that is to be included in the audit records.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior.
Enabling PowerShell script block logging will record detailed information from the processing of PowerShell commands and scripts. This can provide additional detail when malware has run on a system.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn on PowerShell Script Block Logging

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows PowerShell >> "Turn on PowerShell Script Block Logging" to "Enabled"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Remote Management (WinRM) client must not use Basic authentication.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224958
RULE ID: SV-224958r958510

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Employ strong authentication in the establishment of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic sessions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Basic authentication uses plain-text passwords that could be used to compromise a system. Disabling Basic authentication will reduce this potential.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Remote Management (WinRM) >> WinRM Client >> "Allow Basic authentication" to "Disabled"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Remote Management (WinRM) client must not allow unencrypted traffic.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224959
RULE ID: SV-224959r958848

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement organization-defined cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic communications.
Implement organization-defined cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic communications.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Unencrypted remote access to a system can allow sensitive information to be compromised. Windows remote management connections must be encrypted to prevent this.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000393-GPOS-00173, SRG-OS-000394-GPOS-00174

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Remote Management (WinRM) >> WinRM Client >> "Allow unencrypted traffic" to "Disabled"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Remote Management (WinRM) client must not use Digest authentication.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224960
RULE ID: SV-224960r958510

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Employ strong authentication in the establishment of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic sessions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Digest authentication is not as strong as other options and may be subject to man-in-the-middle attacks. Disallowing Digest authentication will reduce this potential.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Remote Management (WinRM) >> WinRM Client >> "Disallow Digest authentication" to "Enabled"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service must not use Basic authentication.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224961
RULE ID: SV-224961r958510

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Employ strong authentication in the establishment of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic sessions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Basic authentication uses plain-text passwords that could be used to compromise a system. Disabling Basic authentication will reduce this potential.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Remote Management (WinRM) >> WinRM Service >> "Allow Basic authentication" to "Disabled".

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service must not allow unencrypted traffic.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224962
RULE ID: SV-224962r958848

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement organization-defined cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic communications.
Implement organization-defined cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic communications.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Unencrypted remote access to a system can allow sensitive information to be compromised. Windows remote management connections must be encrypted to prevent this.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000393-GPOS-00173, SRG-OS-000394-GPOS-00174

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Remote Management (WinRM) >> WinRM Service >> "Allow unencrypted traffic" to "Disabled".

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000550

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service must not store RunAs credentials.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224963
RULE ID: SV-224963r1050790

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The organization requires users to reauthenticate upon organization-defined circumstances or situations requiring reauthentication.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Storage of administrative credentials could allow unauthorized access. Disallowing the storage of RunAs credentials for Windows Remote Management will prevent them from being used with plug-ins.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00157, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Disallow WinRM from storing RunAs credentials

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows Remote Management (WinRM) >> WinRM Service >> "Disallow WinRM from storing RunAs credentials" to "Enabled".

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:title: WN16-CC-000555

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Windows Server 2016 must have PowerShell Transcription enabled.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-257502
RULE ID: SV-257502r958420

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Ensure that audit records containing information that establishes the outcome of the event.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Maintaining an audit trail of system activity logs can help identify configuration errors, troubleshoot service disruptions, and analyze compromises that have occurred, as well as detect attacks. Audit logs are necessary to provide a trail of evidence in case the system or network is compromised. Collecting this data is essential for analyzing the security of information assets and detecting signs of suspicious and unexpected behavior.
Enabling PowerShell Transcription will record detailed information from the processing of PowerShell commands and scripts. This can provide additional detail when malware has run on a system.

cdf12:Rule.cdf12:ident: CIS Recommendation: Turn on PowerShell Transcription

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the policy value for Computer Configuration >> Administrative Templates >> Windows Components >> Windows PowerShell >> "Turn on PowerShell Transcription" to "Enabled".
Specify the Transcript output directory to point to a Central Log Server or another secure location to prevent user access.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Only administrators responsible for the domain controller must have Administrator rights on the system.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224964
RULE ID: SV-224964r958726

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: An account that does not have Administrator duties must not have Administrator rights. Such rights would allow the account to bypass or modify required security restrictions on that machine and make it vulnerable to attack.
System administrators must log on to systems using only accounts with the minimum level of authority necessary.
Standard user accounts must not be members of the built-in Administrators group.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the Administrators group to include only administrator groups or accounts that are responsible for the system.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Kerberos user logon restrictions must be enforced.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224965
RULE ID: SV-224965r958494

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for access to privileged accounts and/or non-privileged accounts.
The information system implements replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to non-privileged accounts.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: This policy setting determines whether the Kerberos Key Distribution Center (KDC) validates every request for a session ticket against the user rights policy of the target computer. The policy is enabled by default, which is the most secure setting for validating that access to target resources is not circumvented.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000112-GPOS-00057, SRG-OS-000113-GPOS-00058

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the policy value in the Default Domain Policy for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Policies >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Account Policies >> Kerberos Policy >> "Enforce user logon restrictions"

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Kerberos service ticket maximum lifetime must be limited to 600 minutes or less.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224966
RULE ID: SV-224966r958494

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for access to privileged accounts and/or non-privileged accounts.
The information system implements replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to non-privileged accounts.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting determines the maximum amount of time (in minutes) that a granted session ticket can be used to access a particular service. Session tickets are used only to authenticate new connections with servers. Ongoing operations are not interrupted if the session ticket used to authenticate the connection expires during the connection.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000112-GPOS-00057, SRG-OS-000113-GPOS-00058

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the policy value in the Default Domain Policy for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Policies >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Account Policies >> Kerberos Policy >> "Maximum lifetime for service ticket"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to a maximum of "600" minutes, but not "0", which equates to "Ticket doesn't expire".

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Kerberos user ticket lifetime must be limited to 10 hours or less.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224967
RULE ID: SV-224967r958494

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for access to privileged accounts and/or non-privileged accounts.
The information system implements replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to non-privileged accounts.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: In Kerberos, there are two types of tickets: Ticket Granting Tickets (TGTs) and Service Tickets. Kerberos tickets have a limited lifetime so the time an attacker has to implement an attack is limited. This policy controls how long TGTs can be renewed. With Kerberos, the user's initial authentication to the domain controller results in a TGT, which is then used to request Service Tickets to resources. Upon startup, each computer gets a TGT before requesting a service ticket to the domain controller and any other computers it needs to access. For services that start up under a specified user account, users must always get a TGT first and then get Service Tickets to all computers and services accessed.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000112-GPOS-00057, SRG-OS-000113-GPOS-00058

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the policy value in the Default Domain Policy for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Policies >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Account Policies >> Kerberos Policy >> "Maximum lifetime for user ticket"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to a maximum of "10" hours but not "0", which equates to "Ticket doesn't expire".

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Kerberos policy user ticket renewal maximum lifetime must be limited to seven days or less.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224968
RULE ID: SV-224968r958494

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for access to privileged accounts and/or non-privileged accounts.
The information system implements replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to non-privileged accounts.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting determines the period of time (in days) during which a user's Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) may be renewed. This security configuration limits the amount of time an attacker has to crack the TGT and gain access.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000112-GPOS-00057, SRG-OS-000113-GPOS-00058

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the policy value in the Default Domain Policy for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Policies >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Account Policies >> Kerberos Policy >> "Maximum lifetime for user ticket renewal"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to a maximum of "7" days or less.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The computer clock synchronization tolerance must be limited to 5 minutes or less.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224969
RULE ID: SV-224969r958494

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for access to privileged accounts and/or non-privileged accounts.
The information system implements replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to non-privileged accounts.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting determines the maximum time difference (in minutes) that Kerberos will tolerate between the time on a client's clock and the time on a server's clock while still considering the two clocks synchronous. In order to prevent replay attacks, Kerberos uses timestamps as part of its protocol definition. For timestamps to work properly, the clocks of the client and the server need to be in sync as much as possible.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000112-GPOS-00057, SRG-OS-000113-GPOS-00058

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the policy value in the Default Domain Policy for
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration >> Windows Settings >> Security Settings >> Account Policies >> Kerberos Policy >> "Maximum tolerance for computer clock synchronization"
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: to a maximum of "5" minutes or less.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Permissions on the Active Directory data files must only allow System and Administrators access.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224970
RULE ID: SV-224970r958726

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Improper access permissions for directory data-related files could allow unauthorized users to read, modify, or delete directory data or audit trails.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Maintain the permissions on NTDS database and log files as follows:
(I) - permission inherited from parent container (F) - full access

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Active Directory SYSVOL directory must have the proper access control permissions.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224971
RULE ID: SV-224971r958726

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Improper access permissions for directory data files could allow unauthorized users to read, modify, or delete directory data.
The SYSVOL directory contains public files (to the domain) such as policies and logon scripts. Data in shared subdirectories are replicated to all domain controllers in a domain.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Maintain the permissions on the SYSVOL directory. Do not allow greater than "Read & execute" permissions for standard user accounts or groups. The defaults below meet this requirement.
C:\Windows\SYSVOL Type - "Allow" for all Inherited from - "None" for all

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Authenticated Users - Read & execute - This folder, subfolder, and files
Server Operators - Read & execute- This folder, subfolder, and files
Administrators - Special - This folder only (Special = Basic Permissions: all selected except Full control)
CREATOR OWNER - Full control - Subfolders and files only
Administrators - Full control - Subfolders and files only
SYSTEM - Full control - This folder, subfolders, and files

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Active Directory Group Policy objects must have proper access control permissions.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224972
RULE ID: SV-224972r958726

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: When directory service database objects do not have appropriate access control permissions, it may be possible for malicious users to create, read, update, or delete the objects and degrade or destroy the integrity of the data. When the directory service is used for identification, authentication, or authorization functions, a compromise of the database objects could lead to a compromise of all systems relying on the directory service.

For Active Directory (AD), the Group Policy objects require special attention. In a distributed administration model (i.e., help desk), Group Policy objects are more likely to have access permissions changed from the secure defaults. If inappropriate access permissions are defined for Group Policy objects, this could allow an intruder to change the security policy applied to all domain client computers (workstations and servers).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Maintain the permissions on Group Policy objects to not allow greater than "Read" and "Apply group policy" for standard user accounts or groups. The default permissions below meet this requirement.
Authenticated Users - Read, Apply group policy, Special permissions
The special permissions for Authenticated Users are for Read-type Properties.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: SYSTEM - Read, Write, Create all child objects, Delete all child objects, Special permissions
Domain Admins - Read, Write, Create all child objects, Delete all child objects, Special permissions
Enterprise Admins - Read, Write, Create all child objects, Delete all child objects, Special permissions
ENTERPRISE DOMAIN CONTROLLERS - Read, Special permissions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Document any other access permissions that allow the objects to be updated with the ISSO.

The Domain Admins and Enterprise Admins will not have the "Delete all child objects" permission on the two default Group Policy objects: Default Domain Policy and Default Domain Controllers Policy. They will have this permission on created Group Policy objects.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Active Directory Domain Controllers Organizational Unit (OU) object must have the proper access control permissions.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224973
RULE ID: SV-224973r958726

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: When Active Directory objects do not have appropriate access control permissions, it may be possible for malicious users to create, read, update, or delete the objects and degrade or destroy the integrity of the data. When the directory service is used for identification, authentication, or authorization functions, a compromise of the database objects could lead to a compromise of all systems that rely on the directory service.

The Domain Controllers OU object requires special attention as the Domain Controllers are central to the configuration and management of the domain. Inappropriate access permissions defined for the Domain Controllers OU could allow an intruder or unauthorized personnel to make changes that could lead to the compromise of the domain.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Limit the permissions on the Domain Controllers OU to restrict changes to System, Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins and Administrators.
The default permissions listed below satisfy this requirement.
Domains supporting Microsoft Exchange will have additional Exchange related permissions on the Domain Controllers OU. These may include some change related permissions.
The special permissions for Authenticated Users are Read types.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Domain Admins - Read, Write, Create all child objects, Generate resultant set of policy (logging), Generate resultant set of policy (planning), Special permissions
Administrators - Read, Write, Create all child objects, Generate resultant set of policy (logging), Generate resultant set of policy (planning), Special permissions
The special permissions for Pre-Windows 2000 Compatible Access are Read types.
ENTERPRISE DOMAIN CONTROLLERS - Read, Special permissions

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Domain-created Active Directory Organizational Unit (OU) objects must have proper access control permissions.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224974
RULE ID: SV-224974r958726

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: When directory service database objects do not have appropriate access control permissions, it may be possible for malicious users to create, read, update, or delete the objects and degrade or destroy the integrity of the data. When the directory service is used for identification, authentication, or authorization functions, a compromise of the database objects could lead to a compromise of all systems that rely on the directory service.

For Active Directory, the OU objects require special attention. In a distributed administration model (i.e., help desk), OU objects are more likely to have access permissions changed from the secure defaults. If inappropriate access permissions are defined for OU objects, it could allow an intruder to add or delete users in the OU. This could result in unauthorized access to data or a denial of service to authorized users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Maintain the permissions on domain-defined OUs to be at least as restrictive as the defaults below.
Document any additional permissions above Read with the ISSO if an approved distributed administration model (help desk or other user support staff) is implemented.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: The special permissions for Authenticated Users are Read type.
Administrators - Read, Write, Create all child objects, Generate resultant set of policy (logging), Generate resultant set of policy (planning), Special permissions
The special permissions for Pre-Windows 2000 Compatible Access are for Read types.
ENTERPRISE DOMAIN CONTROLLERS - Read, Special permissions

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Data files owned by users must be on a different logical partition from the directory server data files.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224975
RULE ID: SV-224975r958524

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: When directory service data files, especially for directories used for identification, authentication, or authorization, reside on the same logical partition as user-owned files, the directory service data may be more vulnerable to unauthorized access or other availability compromises. Directory service and user-owned data files sharing a partition may be configured with less restrictive permissions in order to allow access to the user data.

The directory service may be vulnerable to a denial of service attack when user-owned files on a common partition are expanded to an extent preventing the directory service from acquiring more space for directory or audit data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Move shares used to store files owned by users to a different logical partition than the directory server data files.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Domain controllers must run on a machine dedicated to that function.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224976
RULE ID: SV-224976r958478

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Configure the system to provide only organization-defined mission essential capabilities.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Executing application servers on the same host machine with a directory server may substantially weaken the security of the directory server. Web or database server applications usually require the addition of many programs and accounts, increasing the attack surface of the computer.

Some applications require the addition of privileged accounts, providing potential sources of compromise. Some applications (such as Microsoft Exchange) may require the use of network ports or services conflicting with the directory server. In this case, non-standard ports might be selected, and this could interfere with intrusion detection or prevention services.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Remove additional roles or applications such as web, database, and email from the domain controller.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Separate, NSA-approved (Type 1) cryptography must be used to protect the directory data in transit for directory service implementations at a classified confidentiality level when replication data traverses a network cleared to a lower level than the data.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224977
RULE ID: SV-224977r987791

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Implement organization-defined types of cryptography for each specified cryptography use.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: Directory data that is not appropriately encrypted is subject to compromise. Commercial-grade encryption does not provide adequate protection when the classification level of directory data in transit is higher than the level of the network.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure NSA-approved (Type 1) cryptography to protect the directory data in transit for directory service implementations at a classified confidentiality level that transfer replication data through a network cleared to a lower level than the data.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Directory data (outside the root DSE) of a non-public directory must be configured to prevent anonymous access.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224978
RULE ID: SV-224978r991589

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: To the extent that anonymous access to directory data (outside the root DSE) is permitted, read access control of the data is effectively disabled. If other means of controlling access (such as network restrictions) are compromised, there may be nothing else to protect the confidentiality of sensitive directory data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure directory data (outside the root DSE) of a non-public directory to prevent anonymous access.
For AD, there are multiple configuration items that could enable anonymous access.

Changing the access permissions on the domain naming context object (from the secure defaults) could enable anonymous access. If the check procedures indicate this is the cause, the process that was used to change the permissions should be reversed. This could have been through the Windows Support Tools ADSI Edit console (adsiedit.msc).
The dsHeuristics option is used. This is addressed in check V-8555 in the AD Forest STIG.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The directory service must be configured to terminate LDAP-based network connections to the directory server after 5 minutes of inactivity.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224979
RULE ID: SV-224979r970703

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Terminate the network connection associated with a communications session at the end of the session or after an organization-defined time period of inactivity.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: The failure to terminate inactive network connections increases the risk of a successful attack on the directory server. The longer an established session is in progress, the more time an attacker has to hijack the session, implement a means to passively intercept data, or compromise any protections on client access. For example, if an attacker gains control of a client computer, an existing (already authenticated) session with the directory server could allow access to the directory. The lack of confidentiality protection in LDAP-based sessions increases exposure to this vulnerability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the directory service to terminate LDAP-based network connections to the directory server after 5 minutes of inactivity.
Open an elevated "Command prompt" (run as administrator).
At the "server connections:" prompt, enter "connect to server [host-name]" (where [host-name] is the computer name of the domain controller).
At the "ldap policy:" prompt, enter "Set MaxConnIdleTime to 300".
Enter "q" at the "ldap policy:" and "ntdsutil:" prompts to exit.

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: Active Directory Group Policy objects must be configured with proper audit settings.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224980
RULE ID: SV-224980r958732

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Generate audit records for the event types defined in AU-2 c that include the audit record content defined in AU-3.
Log the execution of privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: When inappropriate audit settings are configured for directory service database objects, it may be possible for a user or process to update the data without generating any tracking data. The impact of missing audit data is related to the type of object. A failure to capture audit data for objects used by identification, authentication, or authorization functions could degrade or eliminate the ability to track changes to access policy for systems or data.

For Active Directory (AD), there are a number of critical object types in the domain naming context of the AD database for which auditing is essential. This includes Group Policy objects. Because changes to these objects can significantly impact access controls or the availability of systems, the absence of auditing data makes it impossible to identify the source of changes that impact the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data and systems throughout an AD domain. The lack of proper auditing can result in insufficient forensic evidence needed to investigate an incident and prosecute the intruder.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000327-GPOS-00127, SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000463-GPOS-00207, SRG-OS-000468-GPOS-00212

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure the audit settings for Group Policy objects to include the following.
This can be done at the Policy level in Active Directory to apply to all group policies.
Open "Active Directory Users and Computers" (available from various menus or run "dsa.msc").
Navigate to [Domain] >> System >> Policies in the left panel.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Applies to - This object and all descendant objects or Descendant groupPolicyContainer objects

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: The three Success types listed below are defaults inherited from the Parent Object. Where Special is listed in the summary screens for Access, detailed Permissions are provided for reference.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Access - Special (Permissions: Write all properties, Modify permissions; Properties: all "Write" type selected)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Two instances with the following summary information will be listed.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Access - blank (Permissions: none selected; Properties: one instance - Write gPLink, one instance - Write gPOptions)
Applies to - Descendant Organization Unit Objects

cdf12:description.xhtml:p: The Active Directory Domain object must be configured with proper audit settings.
cdf12:description.xhtml:code:
GROUP ID: V-224981
RULE ID: SV-224981r958732

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Generate audit records for the event types defined in AU-2 c that include the audit record content defined in AU-3.
Log the execution of privileged functions.

cdf12:rationale.xhtml:p: When inappropriate audit settings are configured for directory service database objects, it may be possible for a user or process to update the data without generating any tracking data. The impact of missing audit data is related to the type of object. A failure to capture audit data for objects used by identification, authentication, or authorization functions could degrade or eliminate the ability to track changes to access policy for systems or data.

For Active Directory (AD), there are a number of critical object types in the domain naming context of the AD database for which auditing is essential. This includes the Domain object. Because changes to these objects can significantly impact access controls or the availability of systems, the absence of auditing data makes it impossible to identify the source of changes that impact the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data and systems throughout an AD domain. The lack of proper auditing can result in insufficient forensic evidence needed to investigate an incident and prosecute the intruder.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000327-GPOS-00127, SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000463-GPOS-00207, SRG-OS-000468-GPOS-00212

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Open "Active Directory Users and Computers" (available from various menus or run "dsa.msc").
Ensure "Advanced Features" is selected in the "View" menu.
Select the domain being reviewed in the left pane.
Right-click the domain name and select "Properties".
Select the "Advanced" button and then the "Auditing" tab.
Configure the audit settings for Domain object to include the following.

The success types listed below are defaults. Where Special is listed in the summary screens for Access, detailed Permissions are provided for reference. Various Properties selections may also exist by default.
Two instances with the following summary information will be listed.

xhtml:li.xhtml:p: (Access - Special = Permissions: Write all properties, Modify permissions, Modify owner.)

GROUP ID: V-224982
RULE ID: SV-224982r958732

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000327-GPOS-00127, SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000463-GPOS-00207, SRG-OS-000468-GPOS-00212

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Open "Active Directory Users and Computers" (available from various menus or run "dsa.msc").
Ensure "Advanced Features" is selected in the "View" menu.
Select the domain being reviewed in the left pane.
Right-click the "Infrastructure" object in the right pane and select "Properties".
Select the "Advanced" button and then the "Auditing" tab.

The success types listed below are defaults. Where Special is listed in the summary screens for Access, detailed Permissions are provided for reference. Various Properties selections may also exist by default.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Open "Active Directory Users and Computers" (available from various menus or run "dsa.msc").
Ensure "Advanced Features" is selected in the "View" menu.
Select the "Domain Controllers OU" under the domain being reviewed in the left pane.
Right-click the "Domain Controllers OU" object and select "Properties".
Select the "Advanced" button and then the "Auditing" tab.
Configure the audit settings for Domain Controllers OU object to include the following.

The success types listed below are defaults. Where Special is listed in the summary screens for Access, detailed Permissions are provided for reference. Various Properties selections may also exist by default.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: (Access - Special = Permissions: all create, delete and modify permissions)
Applies to - This object and all descendant objects

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Two instances with the following summary information will be listed.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Applies to - Descendant Organizational Unit objects
